case_name: Legal representatives of late Mr. Annantrai P. Pattani v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Civil Appeal No.232 of 1960 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.232 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Order dated October 6, 1958, of Bombay High Court in Income Tax Reference No. 10 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated October 6, 1958, of the Bombay High Court in Income Tax Reference No. 10 of 1958.

facts.text: Late Mr. Annantrai P. Pattani appointed Chief Dewan of Bhavnagar State by Hazur Order dated December 10, 1937.

anchor.surface_text: the late Mr. Annantrai P. Pattani, hereinafter called the assessee was, by Hazur Order dated December 10, 1937, appointed the Chief Dewan of Bhavnagar State.

facts.text: On January 15, 1948, Maharaja of Bhavnagar introduced responsible Government and appointed assessee as Chairman of Bhavnagar Durbar Bank without salary.

anchor.surface_text: On January 15, 1948, the Maharaja of Bhavnagar introduced responsible Government in his State and appointed the assessee as the Chairman of the Bhavnagar Durbar Bank but he received nosalary for that post.

facts.text: On January 15, 1948, Maharaja granted monthly pension of Rs. 2,000 to assessee by Hazur Order dated 22-1-1948.

anchor.surface_text: On the same date by another Hazur Order the Maharaja granted a monthly pension of Rs. 2,000 to the assessee. The order was in the following terms He looked after us well in our childhood...

facts.text: On May 31, 1950, Maharaja directed Messrs. Premchand Roychand Sons to pay Rs. 5 lacs to Mr. A.P. Pattani from his account.

anchor.surface_text: On May 31, 1950, the Maharaja directed Messrs. Premchand Roychand Sons, Bombay, with whom he had an account to pay by cheque to Mr. A.P. Pattani Rs. 5 lacs out of the amount lying to the credit of my account with you.

facts.text: Rs. 5 lacs paid to assessee on June 12, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: This sum was paid to the assessee on June 12, 1950.

facts.text: On December 27, 1950, Maharaja ordered Rs. 5 lacs as gift to ex-Diwan for loyal and meritorious services, to be debited to Personal Expense Account.

anchor.surface_text: on December 27, 1950, the Maharaja made the following order- In companysideration of Shri Annantrai P. Pattani the Ex-Diwan of our Bhavnagar State having rendered loyal and meritorious services Rs. 5,00,000  Rupees Five Lacs  are given to him as gift.

facts.text: On March 1, 1948, Bhavnagar State merged in United States of Saurashtra; Maharaja ceased to be ruler.

anchor.surface_text: On March 1, 1948, Bhavnagar State was merged in the United States of Saurashtra and the Maharaja ceased to be the ruler of the said State as from that date.

facts.text: Assessability of Rs. 5 lacs raised in assessment proceedings for 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: The assessability of this sum of Rs. 5 lacs was raised in the companyrse of the assessment proceedings for the assessment year 1951-52

facts.text: On March 10, 1953, Maharaja wrote confirming Rs. 5 lacs as gift token of affection.

anchor.surface_text: the Maharaja wrote on March 10, 1953, the following I companyfirm that in June 1950, 1 gave you a sum of rupees five lacs  Rs. 5,00,000  which wag a gift as a token of my affection and regard for you and your family.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer held Rs. 5,00,000 taxable under s. 7(1) read with explanation 2 for AY 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts the Income-tax Officer held that Rs. 5,00,000 received on June 12, 1950, was liable to income-tax under s. 7 1  read with explanation  2  of that section as it stood before the amendment by the Finance Act, 1955.

facts.text: Appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee took an appeal to the Appellate Assistant -Commissioner which was dismissed.

facts.text: Appeal to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order an appeal was taken to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal but the Tribunal also dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Tribunal held Rs. 5 lacs taxable under s.7(1) expl 2, preferring Dec 27, 1950 order over 1953 letter.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that looking to the circumstances they would attach more importance to the companytemporaneous document, i.e., the order of the 27th December, 1950 which clearly mentioned why the sum of Rs. 5,00,000 was paid to the assessee.

facts.text: Question referred to High Court: Whether Rs. 5 lacs properly brought to tax for AY 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the assessee the following question of law was referred to the High Court Whether the sum of Rs. 5 lacs has been properly ,brought to tax in the hands of the assessee for the assessment year 1951-52?

facts.text: Bombay High Court held s.7(1) expl 2 applied, taxable.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, on the findings given by the Tribunal came to the companyclusion that s. 7 1  explanation  2  of the Income-tax Act applied.

facts.text: Assessee died during High Court proceedings; legal representatives brought on record as appellants.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the proceedings in the High Court the assessee died and his heirs and legal representatives were brought on the record and hence they are the appellants.

facts.text: Pension of Rs. 2000 paid even after merger from public revenue.

anchor.surface_text: which was paid to the assessee even after the merger and of the establishment of the United States of Saurashtra from out of the public revenue.

facts.text: Maharaja was Governor of Madras at time of Rs.5L payment.

anchor.surface_text: The Maharaja was numberlonger a Ruling Chief but was the Governor of the State of Madras.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal allowed by majority; Rs.5L is personal gift, not taxable.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the sum of Rs. 5,00,000 was number paid to the assessee in token of appreciation for the services rendered as a Dewan of Bhavnagar- State but as a personal gift for the personal qualities of the assessee and as a token of personal esteem.

facts.text: Hidayatullah J. dissented, upheld taxability.

anchor.surface_text: I would, therefore, dismiss the appeal with companyts.

facts.text: Tribunal rejected 1953 letter as not believable.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal did number accept the letter of the Maharaja, and observed as follows... we find it difficult to bring ourselves to believe in  sic  the companytents of that letter

facts.text: Payment from Maharaja's personal account with Premchand Roychand Sons.

anchor.surface_text: from moneys in my account with them.

facts.text: Gap of two years between cessation of employment and Rs.5L payment.

anchor.surface_text: it seems to have overlooked the fact that there was a gap of two years before the amount of Rs. 5,00,000 was paid

On these facts the Income-tax Officer held that Rs. 5,00,000 received on June 12, 1950, was liable to income-tax under s. 7 1  read with explanation  2  of that section as it stood before the amendment by the Finance Act, 1955.

concepts.unlisted_description: Treats payments received from former employer as profits in lieu of salary unless solely compensation for loss of employment not by way of remuneration for past services

anchor.surface_text: We would, therefore, hold that the amount of Rs. 5 lacs is a taxable receipt falling under Section 7 1  read with Explanation 2.

concepts.unlisted_description: Treats payments received from former employer as profits in lieu of salary unless solely compensation for loss of employment not by way of remuneration for past services

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, on the findings given by the Tribunal came to the conclusion that s. 7 1  explanation  2  of the Income-tax Act applied.

concepts.unlisted_description: Treats payments received from former employer as profits in lieu of salary unless solely compensation for loss of employment not by way of remuneration for past services

anchor.surface_text: S. 7 1  The tax shall be payable by an assessee under the head Salaries in respect of any salary or wages, any annuity, pension or gratuity and any fees, commissions, perquisites or profits in lieu of, or in addition to, any salary or wages, which are due to him from whether paid or not or are paid by or on behalf of any private employer Explanation 2 A payment due to or received by an assessee from an employer or former employer or from a provident or other fund, is to the extent to, which it does not consist of contributions by the, assessee or interest on such contributions a profit received in lieu of salary for the purpose of this subsection, unless the payment is made solely as compensation for loss of employment and not by way of remuneration for past services

concepts.interpretation: Payment is a personal gift not in lieu of salary or remuneration for past services as assessee already compensated via pension and payment from personal funds post-employment

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: with them. The question in this case was whether s. 7 1  of the Income- tax Act read with Explanation 2 to that section as it stood prior to the amend

concepts.unlisted_description: Treats payments received from former employer as profits in lieu of salary unless solely compensation for loss of employment not by way of remuneration for past services

anchor.surface_text: 7 1 . The tax shall be payable by an assessee under the head Salaries in respect of any salary or wages, any annuity, pension or gratuity and any fees, commissions, perquisites or profits in lieu of, or in addition to, any salary or wages, which are allowed to him by or are due to him, whether paid or not, from, or are paid by or on behalf of any private employer Explanation 2.-A payment due to or received by an assessee from an employer or former employer or from a provident or other fund, is to the extent to which it does not consist of contributions by the assessee or interest on such contributions a profit received in lieu of salary for the purpose of this subsection, unless the payment is made solely as compensation for loss of employment and not by way of remuneration for past services

concepts.interpretation: Payment falls within as remuneration for past services despite called 'gift'; from standpoint of recipient, received by virtue of past office

holdings.text: The sum of Rs. 5,00,000 was not paid to the assessee in token of appreciation for the services rendered as a Dewan of Bhavnagar State but as a personal gift for the personal qualities of the assessee and as a token of personal esteem; therefore not taxable under s.7(1) Explanation 2.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the sum of Rs. 5,00,000 was number paid to the assessee in token of appreciation for the services rendered as a Dewan of Bhavnagar- State but as a personal gift for the personal qualities of the assessee and as a token of personal esteem.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pension already compensated services; payment from personal funds after 2-year gap; Dec 27 order mere accounting entry not contemporaneous; 1953 letter credible; precedents (Beynon v Thorpe, Reed v Seymour, Moorehouse v Dooland) distinguish personal gifts from remuneration.

holdings.text: The Tribunal erred in treating the document of December 27, 1950 as a contemporaneous document; its finding not binding as finding of fact.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that the Tribunal was in error in treating the document of December 27, 1950, as a contemporaneous document and because of this erroneous approach the finding that it has given cannot be treated as a finding of fact

holdings.reasoning_summary: Document written 6 months after payment solely for accounting adjustment; not contemporaneous with payment event.

holdings.text: The payment does not fall within s.7(1) Explanation 2 as not profit in lieu of salary or remuneration for past services.

anchor.surface_text: S. 7 1  The tax shall be payable by an assessee under the head Salaries in respect of any salary or wages, any annuity, pension or gratuity and any fees, commissions, perquisites or profits in lieu of, or in addition to, any salary or wages, which are due to him from whether paid or not or are paid by or on behalf of any private employer Explanation 2 A payment due to or received by an assessee from an employer or former employer

holdings.reasoning_summary: Payment not by way of remuneration for past services but personal gift; assessee already compensated by pension; does not satisfy exception conditions reversely.

holdings.text: Voluntary payment not taxable as salary if not accruing by virtue of office/employment as remuneration, not entitled by contract, not periodic/recurring; here a personal gift.

anchor.surface_text: the test of liability to tax on voluntary payments from the standpoint of the person who receives it was that it accrued to him by virtue of his office or employment, i.e., by way of remuneration of his services  2  that if the assessee's contract of employment entitled him to receive voluntary payments and  3  that the payment was of a periodic and recurring character.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying Moorehouse v Dooland test: payment personal testimonial for qualities, not remuneration; distinguishes P. Krishna Menon as no ongoing vocation/services link.

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed, High Court order set aside, question answered in negative to assessee (against Revenue).

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is therefore allowed and the order of the High Court set aside and the reference is answered against the Commissioner of Income-tax. The appellants will have their companys throughout.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on above substantive holdings reversing lower courts.

anchor.surface_text: Beynon v. Thorpe  1  the assessee resigned his position as a Managing Director of the Company did numberwork for the companypany did  1  1928 14 T.C. 1. number attend any Board meetings and received numberremuneration as a Director of the Company.

precedents.cited_proposition: Sums received after cessation of employment, prompted by gratitude for past services already remunerated, are mere personal gifts not taxable as income from employment or office
precedents.cited_holding: the payments were number income assessable to income-tax [...] it is merely a gift moved by that sort of gratitude or that sort of moral obligation

anchor.surface_text: It has been. made abundantly clear by the Court in Scotland in Duncans case 1  that this sort of sums received by a person cannot possibly be put as receipts from his office or in respect of his office or employment, 1  1909 5 T.C. 417

precedents.cited_proposition: Sums received after ceased employment cannot be taxed as receipts from office or employment

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Kolah also relied on Reed v. Seymour  1 . In that case a companymittee of a Cricket Club granted a benefit match to a professional cricketer in their service.  1  1927 XI T.C. 625.

precedents.cited_proposition: Test whether payment is personal gift or remuneration for services; testimonial expressing gratitude for personal qualities is not taxable
precedents.cited_holding: if the latter it is subject to tax, if the former it is number

anchor.surface_text: Counsel also relied on Moorehouse v. Dooland  2 . In that case a cricket professional was employed under a companytract [...]  2  1955 28 I.T.R. 86.

precedents.cited_proposition: Voluntary payments taxable if accruing by virtue of office/employment as remuneration, periodic/recurring, or contractual; personal testimonial for personal qualities is gift not taxable
precedents.cited_holding: the proceeds were by the terms of the companytract of employment received by way of remuneration and were liable to tax

precedents.citation: David Mitchell v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1

anchor.surface_text: The next case relied upon was David Mitchell v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1  where the test laid was whether the payment was made in appreciation of .the personality  1  1956 30 I.T.R. 701.

precedents.case_name: David Mitchell v Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between payment in appreciation of personality/character vs professional services rendered

precedents.citation: P. Krishna Xenon v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Mysore, Travancore-Cochin and Coorg, Bangalore 1

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondent relied upon a judgment of this Court in P. Krishna Xenon v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Mysore, Travancore-Cochin and Coorg, Bangalore  1 . In that case the assessee  1  1959 Supp. 1 S.C.R. 133.

precedents.case_name: P Krishna Menon v Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Voluntary payments taxable if received by reason of office/vocation even if called gifts; test from recipient's standpoint, not donor's motive
precedents.cited_holding: the point is number what the donor thought he was doing but why the donee received it

precedents.citation: P. Krishna Menon v. The Commissioner of Income- tax, Mysore, Travancore-Cochin and Coorg, Bangalore 1

anchor.surface_text: The case, therefore, falls within the ruling of the a Supreme Court reported in P. Krishna Menon v. The Commissioner of Income- tax, Mysore, Travancore-Cochin and Coorg, Bangalore  1 , and is indistinguishable from it.  1  1959 Supp. 1 S.C.R. 133.

precedents.case_name: P Krishna Menon v Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Payment received from vocation/office as remuneration for past services taxable despite being voluntary gift

anchor.surface_text: Sarkar, J., then referred to the dictum of Collins, M. R., in Herbert v. Mc-Quade  1 , which may be quoted here  1  1902 2 K.B. 631.

precedents.cited_proposition: Payment liable to tax if accrues by virtue of office, regardless of whether voluntary or compulsory
precedents.cited_holding: a payment may be liable to income-tax although it is voluntary on the part of the persons who made it, and that the test is whether, from the standpoint of the person who receives it, it accrues to him in virtue of his office

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge also referred to the observations of Rowlatt, J., in Reed v. Seymour  2  and of Viscount Cave, L. C., in Seymour v. Reed  2  1926 1 K.B. 588.

precedents.cited_proposition: Real question is whether payment is personal gift or remuneration

anchor.surface_text: and of Viscount Cave, L. C., in Seymour v. Reed  3 , and observed that the real question was, is the payment in the nature of a personal gift or is it a remuneration?  3  1927 A.C. 554.

precedents.cited_proposition: Payment is subject to tax if remuneration, not if personal gift
precedents.cited_holding: If the latter, it is subject to the tax if the former, it is number

anchor.surface_text: Sarkar, J., also referred to the observations of Lord Ashbourne in Blakiston Cooper  4 , which were It was suggested that the offerings were made as personal gifts  4  1909 A.C. 104.

precedents.cited_proposition: Offerings given to vicar as vicar form part of profits from office despite personal esteem
precedents.cited_holding: they were given to the vicar as vicar and that they formed part of the profits accruing by reason of his office

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is therefore allowed and the order of the High Court set aside and the reference is answered against the Commissioner of Income-tax. The appellants will have their costs throughout.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; Income-tax reference answered against the Commissioner of Income-tax

anchor.surface_text: S. 7 1  The tax shall be payable by an assessee under the head Salaries in respect of any salary or wages, any annuity, pension or gratuity and any fees, commissions, perquisites or profits in lieu of, or in addition to, any salary or wages, which are due to him from whether paid or not or are paid by or on behalf of any private employer Explanation 2 A payment due to or received by an assessee from an employer or former employer
